_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Wolf Hollow I Power, LLC. Is committed to proactively protecting human health, safety, and the environment.  We operate our business in a manner that conscientiously safeguards our employees, customers, and the community that we operate in.  In striving for responsible environmental, health, and safety (EH&S) stewardship, Wolf Hollow pledges to:
-	Diligently develop, construct, and operate our facilities in an environmentally responsible manner that promotes pollution prevention and places the priority on health and safety.
-	Operate facilities that meet or exceed all applicable federal, state, and local EH&S rules, regulations, ordinances, and statutes as well as recognized industry guidelines and standards.
-	Continually measure, evaluate, and improve our EH&S performance.
-	Promote EH&S awareness that fosters a caring ownership-driven culture among employees, contractors, and vendors.

Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Wolf Hollow I power plant, located in Granbury, Texas, is a gas-fired combustion turbine power plant that produces electricity.  Steam is produced from turbine exhaust gases and used to load a power generator.  As a means of reducing nitrogen oxide emissions from the gas-fired combustion turbine exhaust aqueous ammonia is injected into the turbine exhaust stream.  The aqueous ammonia is stored on-site in storage tanks.  The storage capacity of each storage tank exceeds the threshold quantity for RMP applicability, but the concentration of the aqueous ammonia is lower than the threshold for PSM highly hazardous chemicals set by OSHA.  Therefore, Wolf Hollow is subject to RMP Program 2 requirements.  There are no other toxic or flammable substances on-site that exceed RMP thresholds.

Management System

Wolf Hollow has developed a set of Management System procedures to manage implementation of the elements of the RMP program.  The management system details the scope, purpose, responsibilities and upkeep of eac

h RMP element.
Accidental Release Prevention Program
Wolf Hollow maintains a variety of technical documents to ensure that the process hazards are understood and that the plant is operated and maintained in a safe manner.  The documents include information concerning the hazards of aqueous ammonia process technology and process equipment.  This information is updated when changes in the process occur.

Hazard Analysis

Wolf Hollow has a comprehensive program to ensure that the hazards associated with the processes are systematically identified and controlled.  The analysis is conducted in accordance with regulatory requirements, generally accepted industry standards, and guidelines from safety organizations such as the Center for Chemical Process Safety.  Wolf Hollow has a system in place to ensure that the analysis recommendations are resolved in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures

Wolf Hollow maintains written operating procedures that address the modes of process operations including initial startup, normal startups and shutdowns, emergency shutdowns, emergency operations, normal operations, and temporary operations.  The procedures also discuss safe upper and lower process limits, consequences deviation from the safe limits, and how to return the process to safe operations.  The procedures are readily available to operations personnel and are reviewed annually by team leaders.

Training

All operating personnel at Wolf Hollow are initially trained in an overview of the aqueous ammonia process and the procedures for safely operating the process.  Operations personnel receive refresher training every three years, at a minimum.  In addition, all employees are given general awareness training on RMP, the hazards of aqueous ammonia, and general emergency response.

Maintenance

Wolf Hollow has implemented practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, and emergency shutdown system

s in a safe operating condition.  The program includes: (1) the development of a maintenance schedule for equipment in the aqueous ammonia process, (2) developing written maintenance procedures, (3) conducting maintenance training, (4) performing and documenting inspections, (5) correcting identifiable equipment deficiencies, and (6) applying quality assurance measures to ensure replacement equipment meets the required specifications.

Incident Investigation

Wolf Hollow promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably be expected to result in, the release of ammonia.  The findings of the investigation along with any corrective actions taken to prevent recurrence of the incident, will be reviewed with all affected personnel, including contractors.

Compliance Audits

To ensure that the accidental release prevention program is functioning properly Wolf Hollow conducts a performance audit every three years. The plant quickly resolves any deficiencies noted by the audit team and reviews the audit report and corrective actions taken with all affected personnel.

Additional Safety Systems

Wolf Hollow has additional systems in place to prevent accidental releases of ammonia as well as systems to lessen the impact of accidental releases.  These system include:
-	Pressure relief valves;
-	Shut off valves; and 
-	Level gauges and indicators.

Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of ammonia at Wolf Hollow in the past five years.

Emergency Response Plan

Wolf Hollow maintains a written defensive emergency response program.  The program addresses appropriate aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans, personnel accounting, notification of emergency response agencies and the public in the event of a release.  The emergency response program is coordinated with the Hood County LEPC.
